artist: Artist: Utagawa Hiroshige; Publisher: Wakasaya Yoichi
creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
inscription: The story is about Ariwara-no Narihira and miyako-dori birds. One evening Narihira and his attendant came over by the Sumida River. It was winter; everthing looked desolate and depressing. The scenery made him miss the city (probably Kyoto) where he used to live and the friends he knew there quite a lot. Then he noticed some pretty white birds flying over the river. He asked the locals what kind of birds they are. He was told they are called \"miyako-dori\" (city-birds). He found it an interesting coincidence that city-birds flew to him when he was thinking of city.
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Old Landmarks of the Eastern Capital (Tōto kyūseki zukushi)
title: Old Story of Miyako-dori Gulls and the Sumida River
